MEANING: so great in size, force, or extent as to elicit awe
BREIF: Stupendous means amazing or awesome. You just won a million dollars and are donating it to charity? That’s stupendous!
ADJECTIVE: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe

MEANING: an artificial or inferior substitute or imitation
BREIF: The ersatz version of something is an inferior substitute or imitation. You might speak in an ersatz French accent, but you won't fool the Parisian who runs the local French bakery.
NOUN: an artificial or inferior substitute or imitation
ADJECTIVE: artificial and inferior

MEANING: scold or reprimand; take to task
BREIF: To admonish is to scold. If you want to show someone you're not happy with his behavior, admonish him.

VERB: admonish or counsel in terms of someone's behavior

MEANING: someone new to a field or activity
BREIF: A tyro is a beginner, a new recruit, or someone who is just learning something. If you are the new guy at the job and you're wearing a big badge that says "Trainee" on it, you are a tyro.
NOUN: someone new to a field or activity

MEANING: a drug or other agent that stimulates sexual desire
BREIF: An aphrodisiac is a drug (or something else) that puts people in the mood for sex.
NOUN: a drug or other agent that stimulates sexual desire
ADJECTIVE: exciting sexual desire

MEANING: smear so as to make dirty or stained
BREIF: To besmirch means to dirty or tarnish, particularly someone's reputation — like when you call Billy a cheater at kickball (even though you know he's just better at bunting than you).
VERB: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of someone
smear so as to make dirty or stained

MEANING: hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases
BREIF: If someone offers you a pill that promises eternal life, don’t take the pill.  It’s a panacea, a remedy that falsely claims to solve every problem ever.
NOUN: hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases; once sought by the alchemists

MEANING: descriptive word or phrase
BREIF: The noun epithet is a descriptive nickname, such as "Richard the Lionhearted," or "Tommy the Terrible." When it takes a turn for the worse, it can also be a word or phrase that offends.
NOUN: a defamatory or abusive word or phrase
descriptive word or phrase

MEANING: expel from a community or group
BREIF: If you banish someone or ignore him, you ostracize him. When the Iranian president claimed that the Holocaust was a hoax, he was ostracized by the international community.
VERB: avoid speaking to or dealing with
expel from a community or group

MEANING: an innocuous or inert medication
BREIF: A patient's symptoms sometimes disappear just because they believe that they are being treated. Even when doctors give them a biologically inactive drug, otherwise known as a placebo, the patients swear they are cured.
NOUN: (Roman Catholic Church) vespers of the office for the dead
an innocuous or inert medication; given as a pacifier or to the control group in experiments on the efficacy of a drug

MEANING: a complete failure or collapse
BREIF: A fiasco is a disaster. It's not a natural disaster — like an earthquake or a volcano; a fiasco is usually the result of human failure.
NOUN: a complete failure or collapse

MEANING: a classification into two opposed parts or subclasses
BREIF: A dichotomy is an idea or classification split in two. When you point out a dichotomy, you draw a clear distinction between two things.
NOUN: being twofold; a classification into two opposed parts or subclasses

MEANING: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose
BREIF: Have you noticed how so many of the best TV shows concentrate on a group of friends who seem to mesh together perfectly, to the exclusion of all others? This, then, is a coterie, an exclusive group with common interests.
NOUN: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose

MEANING: an inoffensive expression substituted for an offensive one
BREIF: Pardon me, but when a polite term is substituted for a blunt, offensive one, you should call it a euphemism.
NOUN: an inoffensive or indirect expression that is substituted for one that is considered offensive or too harsh

MEANING: a fervent and even militant proponent of something
BREIF: The hamburger zealot was so fanatical about his burgers that he camped outside his favorite fast-food joint for hours every morning, waiting for it to open. And he would never put mustard on them, only ketchup.
NOUN: a fervent and even militant proponent of something

MEANING: attract strongly, as if with a magnet
BREIF: You meet someone and you can’t take your eyes off them, like you are connected by an invisible cord and can’t break free.  Those kinds of people have the power to mesmerize, holding your attention like you’re under hypnosis.

VERB: attract strongly, as if with a magnet

MEANING: a perfect embodiment of a concept
BREIF: Paragon applies to someone who is a model of perfection in some quality or trait. We link paragon with other words that follow it, such as "paragon of virtue" or "paragon of patience."
NOUN: model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal
an ideal instance; a perfect embodiment of a concept

MEANING: an amateur engaging in an activity without serious intention
BREIF: Though dilettante might sound like a nice French word, don't use it on your friend who thinks he can play the guitar after several short lessons. A dilettante is an amateur, often one who pretends to be very knowledgeable.
NOUN: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
ADJECTIVE: showing frivolous or superficial interest; amateurish

MEANING: extravagant exaggeration
BREIF: Praising your favorite sports team is one thing, but if you call the team the most incredible group of humans ever to walk the earth, then you're going overboard and indulging in hyperbole.
NOUN: extravagant exaggeration

MEANING: recklessly wasteful
BREIF: Extravagant is an adjective that means expensive, excessive, and over the top. A modest chandelier in your dining room is normal. But crystal-studded walls and gold-plated goblets? That's a bit extravagant.
ADJECTIVE: unrestrained, especially with regard to feelings
recklessly wasteful
extremely or unreasonably high in price
greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation

MEANING: a person who pays too much attention to formal rules
BREIF: A pedant is an annoying person who is focused on minor details and book knowledge rather than ordinary common sense. In war, it can be dangerous to have a pedant as commander — he'll insist on textbook maneuvers instead of adapting to circumstances on the ground.
NOUN: a person who pays more attention to formal rules and book learning than they merit

MEANING: model of excellence or perfection of a kind
BREIF: If your teacher says the term paper you handed in last week is a work of genius that sets a new gold standard for the school, he's telling you your work is the apotheosis of term papers. The epitome. Perfection.
NOUN: the elevation of a person (as to the status of a god)
model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal

MEANING: a person who tries to please someone to gain an advantage
BREIF: A sycophant is a person who tries to win favor from wealthy or influential people by flattering them. Also known as brown-nosers, teacher's pets or suck-ups.
NOUN: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage

MEANING: a doctrine or code of beliefs accepted as authoritative
BREIF: Dogma means the doctrine of belief in a religion or a political system.
NOUN: a religious doctrine that is proclaimed as true without proof
a doctrine or code of beliefs accepted as authoritative

MEANING: someone who dislikes people in general
BREIF: A misanthrope is a person who hates or mistrusts other people. Your great aunt Edna who lashes out at anyone who approaches, convinced they'll steal the jewelry she keeps in her handbag on her lap? A misanthrope indeed.
NOUN: someone who dislikes people in general

MEANING: disagreeable sounds
BREIF: Disagreeable sounds can be called dissonance. You know it's dissonance if you have the strong desire to cover your ears with your hands.
NOUN: a conflict of people's opinions or actions or characters
disagreeable sounds
the auditory experience of sound that lacks musical quality; sound that is a disagreeable auditory experience

MEANING: overly dramatic or emotional
BREIF: Anything that has to do with actors or acting can be called  histrionic, like a Broadway actor's histrionic voice projection that would sound strange in everyday life but is perfect for the stage.
ADJECTIVE: characteristic of acting or a stage performance; affected
overly dramatic or emotional

MEANING: understandable only by an enlightened inner circle
BREIF: Pssst... do you know the secret handshake? If you haven't been brought into the inner circle of those with special knowledge, esoteric things will remain a mystery to you.
ADJECTIVE: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle

MEANING: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
BREIF: Use nuance to refer to a very small difference in color, meaning, or feeling. What makes singers brilliant is not how loud they can sing a note, but how many nuances they can evoke through their approach.
NOUN: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude

MEANING: a serious devotee of some activity, genre, or performer
BREIF: If you really like something and make it your business to study up on its history and characteristics, you could be called an aficionado of that subject.
NOUN: a fan of bull fighting
a serious devotee of some particular music genre or musical performer

MEANING: peculiar to the individual
BREIF: Idiosyncratic means unique to an individual. Albert Einstein famously had lots of idiosyncratic habits.  For example, he rarely wore socks, and he talked to his cat.
ADJECTIVE: peculiar to the individual

MEANING: category name
BREIF: A rubric is a heading or a category in a chart, or a rule of conduct. A teacher's grading rubrics may include participation, homework completion, tests, quizzes, and papers.
NOUN: an explanation or definition of an obscure word in a text

MEANING: a composition that imitates or misrepresents a style
BREIF: A travesty is a cheap mockery, usually of something or someone serious, such as a travesty of justice.
NOUN: a distorted, debased, or absurd imitation of something

MEANING: the power to foresee the future
BREIF: Do you already know what happens tomorrow? Next week? Next year? If you can see into the future, then you have prescience.
NOUN: the power to foresee the future

MEANING: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
BREIF: When you are unwilling to make a decision and almost intentionally go back and forth between two choices, you are equivocating. When politicians equivocate, they are often afraid of upsetting, and thus alienating, voters with their decisions.
VERB: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear in order to mislead or withhold information

MEANING: anger produced by some annoying irritation
BREIF: Vexation is both something that causes annoyance and the state of mind that results from being annoyed. The test-taker next to you tapping her pencil is a vexation. You breaking her pencil in half makes her feel vexation.
NOUN: the act of troubling or annoying someone
anger produced by some annoying irritation
the psychological state of being irritated or annoyed
something or someone that causes anxiety; a source of unhappiness

MEANING: resoluteness by virtue of being unyielding and inflexible
NOUN: resoluteness by virtue of being unyielding and inflexible

MEANING: the domain controlled by a feudal lord
NOUN: an organization that is controlled by a dominant person or group
the domain controlled by a feudal lord

MEANING: locating something at a time when it couldn't have existed
BREIF: An anachronism is something that doesn't fit its time period, like if you say you'll "dial" your smartphone.
NOUN: a person who seems to be displaced in time; who belongs to another age
the act of locating something at a time when it could not have existed or occurred
an artifact that belongs to another time

MEANING: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible
BREIF: Something that is egregious stands out, but not in a good way — it means "really bad or offensive." If you make an egregious error during a championship soccer match, your coach might bench you for the rest of the game.
ADJECTIVE: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible

MEANING: the property of being extremely abundant
BREIF: If there's an abundance of something, you can say that there's a profusion of it. Hilarious and bizarre YouTube videos certainly exist in profusion.
NOUN: the property of being extremely abundant

MEANING: a rough and bitter manner
BREIF: Acrimony is bitterness, or ill will. Acrimony is a spiteful word. It sounds bitter, like acid.
NOUN: a rough and bitter manner

MEANING: make worse
BREIF: For a formal-sounding verb that means to make worse, try exacerbate. If you're in trouble, complaining about it will only exacerbate the problem.

MEANING: an irascible, cantankerous person full of stubborn ideas
BREIF: Old, cranky, and more than a little stubborn, a curmudgeon is the gruff, grey-haired neighbor who refuses to hand out candy at Halloween and shoos away holiday carolers with a "bah humbug!"
NOUN: a crusty irascible cantankerous old person full of stubborn ideas

MEANING: not injurious to physical or mental health
BREIF: Something that's innocuous isn't harmful or likely to cause injury. Public figures like mayors and governors have to expect they'll get critical or even hurtful emails and phone calls, as well as more innocuous feedback.
ADJECTIVE: not causing disapproval
not injurious to physical or mental health
lacking intent or capacity to injure

MEANING: a formal ecclesiastical curse accompanied by excommunication
BREIF: Something that one absolutely and positively cannot stand is anathema. Garlic is anathema to vampires (ditto for stakes and daylight). So is kryptonite to Superman or a silver bullet to a werewolf.
NOUN: something that inspires dislike; something horrible
a formal ecclesiastical curse accompanied by excommunication
a detested person or thing

MEANING: having or showing arrogant superiority
BREIF: Someone who is haughty is arrogant and full of pride. When you're haughty, you have a big attitude and act like you're better than other people.
ADJECTIVE: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy

MEANING: rigorous self-denial and active self-restraint
BREIF: Asceticism is rigorous self-denial, particularly the rejection of the pleasures of the world. If you don't drink, smoke, eat sugar, see movies, use the internet, or have a cell phone, then you are already practicing a kind of asceticism.
NOUN: the doctrine that through renunciation of worldly pleasures it is possible to achieve a high spiritual or intellectual state
rigorous self-denial and active self-restraint
the trait of great self-denial (especially refraining from worldly pleasures)

MEANING: formal and explicit approval
BREIF: If you give something your imprimatur, you give it your formal support or approval. An imprimatur is a fancy version of a thumbs-up sign.
NOUN: formal and explicit approval

MEANING: disdainfully or ironically humorous
BREIF: If someone is being scornful and mocking in a humorous way, call her sardonic. If you want to write comic sketches for late-night talk shows, work on being sardonic.
ADJECTIVE: disdainfully or ironically humorous; scornful and mocking

MEANING: make better
BREIF: To ameliorate is to step in and make a bad situation better. You could try introducing a second lollipop to ameliorate a battle between two toddlers over a single lollipop.

MEANING: a corrupt or depraved or degenerate act or practice
BREIF: If you are guilty of turpitude, you should be ashamed of yourself. Turpitude is a word that represents depraved behavior. Prisons are filled with criminals who have engaged in acts of moral turpitude.
NOUN: a corrupt or depraved or degenerate act or practice

MEANING: the act of delaying and playing instead of working
BREIF: A dalliance is a playful flirtation, one that might lead to a casual romance. The king's public dalliance toward the lady in waiting shocked everyone in the court except for the queen.
NOUN: playful behavior intended to arouse romantic interest
the deliberate act of delaying and playing instead of working

MEANING: a person who has taught himself
BREIF: If you're an autodidact you've done most of your learning on your own, outside of school. Having learned Greek and Latin, as well as landscape painting and auto repair, without any formal training makes you quite the autodidact.
NOUN: a person who has taught himself

MEANING: short-lived; tending to vanish or disappear
BREIF: A beautiful sunset, a rainbow, a wonderful dream right before your alarm clock goes off — all of these could be described as evanescent, which means “fleeting” or “temporary.”
ADJECTIVE: tending to vanish like vapor

MEANING: an intervening period or episode
BREIF: An interlude is a brief period of time that comes in the middle of something. You might enjoy a relaxing lemonade interlude in the middle of a tough day at your road-paving job.
NOUN: a brief show (music or dance etc) inserted between the sections of a longer performance

MEANING: shy or modest, often in a playful or provocative way
BREIF: A demure person can be described as polite and a little shy. A demure outfit is a modest one — think high neckline and low hem.
ADJECTIVE: (used especially of clothing) suggestive of modesty or reserve
affectedly modest or shy especially in a playful or provocative way

MEANING: pleasing to the ear
BREIF: Use the adjective mellifluous to describe something that sounds sweet and smooth, like the honeyed voice of a late-night radio DJ.
ADJECTIVE: pleasing to the ear

MEANING: pleasing and appropriate manner or style
BREIF: Felicity is a state of happiness or the quality of joy. Sitting on the roof with a telescope and iced tea on a clear, starry night is one way to find perfect felicity — a happy place.
NOUN: state of well-being characterized by emotions ranging from contentment to intense joy
pleasing and appropriate manner or style (especially manner or style of expression)

MEANING: an intricate and confusing interpersonal situation
BREIF: An imbroglio is a complicated or confusing personal situation. To rephrase the J. Geils band song, "Love Stinks," if you love her and she loves him and he loves somebody else, you've got quite an imbroglio.
NOUN: a very embarrassing misunderstanding
an intricate and confusing interpersonal or political situation

MEANING: a casual or lighthearted feeling of unconcern
BREIF: Insouciance is a feeling of careless indifference. There's a certain amount of lightheartedness in insouciance, but rather than merely being cheerful, someone with insouciance truly couldn't care less.
NOUN: the cheerful feeling you have when nothing is troubling you

MEANING: a feeling of lack of interest or energy
BREIF: If you are feeling lassitude, you're weary and just can't be bothered. Couch potatoes make lassitude into an art form.
NOUN: a state of comatose torpor (as found in sleeping sickness)
a feeling of lack of interest or energy
weakness characterized by a lack of vitality or energy

MEANING: transparently clear; easily understandable
BREIF: Something that's lucid is clear and understandable. Lucid writing is important in journalism, so that readers easily get the point of the article they're reading.
ADJECTIVE: transmitting light; able to be seen through with clarity
(of language) transparently clear; easily understandable
having a clear mind
capable of thinking and expressing yourself in a clear and consistent manner

MEANING: relating to the abode of the blessed after death
BREIF: The adjective elysian describes a blissful state, like the one most people hope to enjoy on a Hawaiian vacation.
ADJECTIVE: being of such surpassing excellence as to suggest inspiration by the gods
relating to the Elysian Fields

MEANING: a participant with no experience with an activity
BREIF: A neophyte is someone who's brand new at something. You're a neophyte the first time you pick up a guitar and start learning to play.
NOUN: a plant that is found in an area where it had not been recorded previously
a participant with no experience with an activity
a new convert being taught the principles of Christianity by a catechist

MEANING: a state of being carried away by overwhelming emotion
BREIF: Rapture is a feeling of emotional ecstasy so magical it's almost as if you've been transported to some other world.
NOUN: a state of elated bliss
a state of being carried away by overwhelming emotion

MEANING: serving to bring to mind
BREIF: Use the adjective evocative when you want to describe something that reminds you of something else. If your mom baked a lot when you were a kid, the smell of cookies in the oven is probably evocative of your childhood.
ADJECTIVE: serving to bring to mind

MEANING: a feeling of intense dislike
BREIF: An antipathy is a deep-seated dislike of something or someone. Usually it's a condition that is long-term, innate, and pretty unlikely to change — like your antipathy for the Red Sox.
NOUN: the object of a feeling of intense aversion; something to be avoided
a feeling of intense dislike

MEANING: a natural attraction or feeling of kinship
BREIF: If you get along with someone very well, you have an affinity with them. Sometimes opposites attract, so you might feel a strange affinity to someone who is seemingly very different from you.
NOUN: (immunology) the attraction between an antigen and an antibody
a natural attraction or feeling of kinship
a close connection marked by community of interests or similarity in nature or character
(anthropology) kinship by marriage or adoption; not a blood relationship

MEANING: understanding and entering into another's feelings
BREIF: Use empathy if you're looking for a noun meaning "the ability to identify with another's feelings."
NOUN: understanding and entering into another's feelings

MEANING: deviation from the normal or common order, form, or rule
BREIF: An anomaly is an abnormality, a blip on the screen of life that doesn’t fit with the rest of the pattern. If you are a breeder of black dogs and one puppy comes out pink, that puppy is an anomaly.
NOUN: (astronomy) position of a planet as defined by its angular distance from its perihelion (as observed from the sun)
deviation from the normal or common order or form or rule
a person who is unusual

MEANING: the common people generally
BREIF: The hoi polloi is a way of referring to common people, and it is an elitist term usually used by people who consider themselves to be above the masses.
NOUN: the common people generally

MEANING: more important than anything else; supreme
BREIF: To the President, protecting our nation's security is of paramount importance — it's at the very top of his to-do list.
ADJECTIVE: having superior power or influence
more important than anything else; supreme

MEANING: provoke the hostility of
BREIF: To antagonize is to provoke someone to react angrily. If your mother tells you to stop antagonizing your brother, she's asking you to stop making him mad.

MEANING: complete and without qualification
BREIF: The word arrant intensifies. An arrant criminal is one heck of a criminal. Arrant nonsense is total nonsense.
ADJECTIVE: without qualification; used informally as (often pejorative) intensifiers

MEANING: straying from the right course or from accepted standards
BREIF: Something or someone described as errant has gone astray or done wrong by going in an unexpected direction. An errant bird might end up in northern Canada while his friends fly to southern Mexico for the winter.
ADJECTIVE: traveling from place to place, especially in search of adventure
straying from the right course or from accepted standards
moving in an uncontrolled, irregular, or unpredictable way

MEANING: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
BREIF: If you adulterate something, you mess it up. You may not want to adulterate the beauty of freshly fallen snow by shoveling it, but how else are you going to get to work?
VERB: corrupt, debase, or make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance; often by replacing valuable ingredients with inferior ones
ADJECTIVE: mixed with impurities

MEANING: overcome as with astonishment or disbelief
VERB: overcome as with astonishment or disbelief

MEANING: lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful
BREIF: A craven man is no Superman or Spiderman, nor is he a firefighter or a soldier. A craven man is the opposite of those guys: he has not an ounce of courage.
NOUN: an abject coward
ADJECTIVE: lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful

MEANING: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
BREIF: When you prevaricate, you lie or mislead. Now, go ahead and tell me whether you already knew that meaning, and don’t prevaricate about it — give me the story straight!
VERB: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear in order to mislead or withhold information

MEANING: temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
BREIF: If you know someone who's outgoing, sociable, and fond of the company of others, you might want to call her gregarious.
ADJECTIVE: (of plants) growing in groups that are close together
instinctively or temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
(of animals) tending to form a group with others of the same species

MEANING: someone who attacks cherished ideas or institutions
BREIF: Are you always challenging the establishment? Or provoking popular thought by attacking traditions and institutions? Then you're definitely an iconoclast.
NOUN: a destroyer of images used in religious worship
someone who attacks cherished ideas or traditional institutions

MEANING: attack someone physically or emotionally
BREIF: To assail is to attack or assault — with throwing stars, fists, words or, less tangibly but just as violently, with troubles or doubts.
VERB: launch an attack or assault on; begin hostilities or start warfare with

MEANING: speak out against
BREIF: To denounce is to tattle, rat out, or speak out against something. When you stand on your desk and tell the class that your partner is cheating, you denounce him or her.
VERB: announce the termination of, as of treaties
accuse or condemn openly or formally as disgraceful

MEANING: inflict severe punishment on
BREIF: Use castigate  when you mean "to reprimand in an especially harsh way." If you accidentally spill coffee all over your sister's favorite sweater, you might worry that she's going to castigate you as soon as she finds out.

MEANING: thunderous verbal attack
BREIF: It's pretty overwhelming when you ask your friend a seemingly innocuous question, like "Do you like hot dogs?" and she unleashes a diatribe about the evils of eating meat. A diatribe is an angry, critical speech.
NOUN: thunderous verbal attack

MEANING: express strong disapproval of
BREIF: When it comes to “telling someone off,” excoriate is reserved for the most severe cases. So, before you excoriate your little sister for borrowing your favorite jacket without permission, consider whether she truly deserves such harsh treatment.
VERB: tear or wear off the skin or make sore by abrading

MEANING: cause to explode violently and with loud noise
BREIF: Watch a bomb fulminate or explode and hope you're under safe cover. Have your parents fulminate or blow up at you for coming home past curfew and hope you're not grounded for too long.
NOUN: a salt or ester of fulminic acid

MEANING: ostentatiously lofty in style
BREIF: To be bombastic is to be full of hot air — like a politician who makes grand promises and doesn't deliver.
ADJECTIVE: ostentatiously lofty in style

MEANING: censure severely or angrily
BREIF: To lambaste is to reprimand or berate someone severely. People lambaste those who have angered or disappointed them.

MEANING: spread negative information about
BREIF: If something is reviled, you alone don’t dislike it; a whole community of like-minded souls has to hate its guts. For instance, spam is widely reviled. (The junk e-mails, not the potted meat. Somebody out there really does like that potted meat.)

MEANING: a speech of violent denunciation
BREIF: A tirade is a speech, usually consisting of a long string of violent, emotionally charged words. Borrow and lose your roommate’s clothes one too many times, and you can bet you’ll be treated to a heated tirade.
NOUN: a speech of violent denunciation

MEANING: express criticism towards
BREIF: No, upbraid isn’t an elaborate hairdo. When you upbraid people, you scold them, tell them off, and criticize them. (You could, however, upbraid your stylist after a bad haircut.)

MEANING: beat thoroughly and conclusively in a competition or fight
VERB: beat thoroughly and conclusively in a competition or fight

MEANING: make into a powder by breaking up or cause to become dust
BREIF: When you pulverize something, you break it up until it becomes dust or powder. You might pulverize coffee beans in grinder, running it until the coffee turns to powder.

VERB: make into a powder by breaking up or cause to become dust

MEANING: make subservient; force to submit or subdue
BREIF: If you say you won't be kept down by the man, you are saying that you won't let the man subjugate you. To subjugate is to repress someone, or to make them subservient to you.
VERB: put down by force or intimidation
make subservient; force to submit or subdue

MEANING: defeat in a competition, race, or conflict
BREIF: To vanquish is to be the complete and total winner, to overpower and overcome, whether in a contest, a race, or a war. It generally suggests a total trouncing, to the point of humiliation — or worse — for the loser.
VERB: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict

MEANING: surrender under agreed conditions
BREIF: To capitulate means to give in to something. If your parents refuse to raise your allowance, you might try to argue until they capitulate. Good luck!

MEANING: a proposition that is not susceptible of proof or disproof
BREIF: An axiom is a statement that everyone believes is true, such as "the only constant is change." Mathematicians use the word axiom to refer to an established proof.
NOUN: a saying that is widely accepted on its own merits
(logic) a proposition that is not susceptible of proof or disproof; its truth is assumed to be self-evident

MEANING: official acceptance or agreement
BREIF: Approbation is a formal word for approval or praise. Approbation is like getting the nod in a big way. Politicians rely on the public’s approbation to get elected.
NOUN: official recognition or approval
official approval

MEANING: characteristic of an enemy or one eager to fight
BREIF: If someone is belligerent, they're eager to fight. It's a good idea to avoid hardcore hockey fans after their team loses — they tend to be belligerent.
NOUN: someone who fights (or is fighting)
ADJECTIVE: engaged in war

MEANING: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
BREIF: Capricious is an adjective to describe a person or thing that's impulsive and unpredictable, like a bride who suddenly leaves her groom standing at the wedding altar.
ADJECTIVE: changeable
determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason

MEANING: an act or expression of criticism and censure
BREIF: If you're reprimanded, someone in authority speaks to you in an angry way because you've done something wrong. Or you might reprimand your dog if he steals your hot dog.
NOUN: an act or expression of criticism and censure
an act or expression of criticism and censure

MEANING: marked by or showing unaffected simplicity
BREIF: No one likes being called naive, since it means you lack sophistication or street smarts.
ADJECTIVE: of or created by one without formal training; simple or naive in style
marked by or showing unaffected simplicity and lack of guile or worldly experience
lacking information or instruction
inexperienced

MEANING: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
BREIF: Someone who doesn't seem to react — who is always "taking a pass" in the conversation of life can be described as impassive.
ADJECTIVE: deliberately impassive in manner
having or revealing little emotion or sensibility; not easily aroused or excited

MEANING: liable to sudden unpredictable change
BREIF: The adjective erratic describes things that are unpredictable, unusual, and that deviate from the norm. An erratic quarterback might completely confuse his receivers waiting for a pass.
ADJECTIVE: having no fixed course
liable to sudden unpredictable change
likely to perform unpredictably

MEANING: unwillingness to tell lies
BREIF: Veracity sounds like some kind of disease you don't want to catch, but in fact, it means truthfulness. If you question the veracity of a statement or story, you wonder whether it is truthful or accurate.
NOUN: unwillingness to tell lies

MEANING: using or containing too many words
BREIF: If you're verbose, you use far more words than you need to. A verbose book report goes on and on and is packed with long, complicated words that aren't at all necessary.
ADJECTIVE: using or containing too many words

MEANING: full of anxiety and concern
BREIF: When you hear the word solicitous, think of your mom — attentive, caring, and concerned. It's nice when your waiter gives you good service, but if he or she is solicitous, the hovering might annoy you.
ADJECTIVE: showing hovering attentiveness
full of anxiety and concern

MEANING: run away, often taking something or somebody along
BREIF: Abscond is to escape, often taking something along. As a kid, you may have absconded from your lemonade stand — with the coffee can of cash in hand, and your bewildered sister still filling cups for your customers.
VERB: run away; usually includes taking something or somebody along

MEANING: deficient in alertness or activity
BREIF: When you feel lethargic, you're sluggish or lacking energy. Being sleepy or hungry can make anyone lethargic.
ADJECTIVE: deficient in alertness or activity

MEANING: cause to become widely known
BREIF: Disseminate means to spread information, knowledge, opinions widely. Semin- derives from the Latin word for seed; the idea with disseminate is that information travels like seeds sown by a farmer.

MEANING: potentially existing but not presently evident or realized
BREIF: Latent is an adjective that you use to describe something that is capable of becoming active or at hand, though it is not currently so.
ADJECTIVE: (pathology) not presently active
potentially existing but not presently evident or realized

MEANING: markedly different from an accepted norm
BREIF: Use the adjective aberrant to describe unusual conduct. Sitting in a bathtub and singing show tunes all day long might be considered aberrant behavior.
NOUN: one whose behavior departs substantially from the norm of a group
ADJECTIVE: markedly different from an accepted norm

MEANING: uncertain or unable to decide about what course to follow
BREIF: If you can't decide how you feel about something, declare yourself ambivalent about it.
ADJECTIVE: uncertain or unable to decide about what course to follow

MEANING: having an offensive smell or taste
BREIF: Rancid means sour, rotten, and nasty and refers most specifically to the sharp bad smell of decomposing oils or fats. "Rancid" is a great name for a post-punk band, but a lousy way to describe the sauce on your eggs Benedict.
ADJECTIVE: smelling of fermentation or staleness
(used of decomposing oils or fats) having a rank smell or taste usually due to a chemical change or decomposition

MEANING: showing deep-seated resentment
BREIF: The adjective rancorous comes in handy when you're describing someone's bitter grudge, like the attitude of your cousin who still won't speak to you after the April Fool's Day prank you played four years ago.
ADJECTIVE: showing deep-seated resentment

MEANING: showing a lack of concern or seriousness
BREIF: Someone who is cavalier has a dismissive attitude and regards other people as inferior. If you think you know more than your teacher and never bother doing homework, your parents might complain that you are cavalier about your studies.
NOUN: a gallant or courtly gentleman
ADJECTIVE: given to haughty disregard of others

MEANING: showing unselfish concern for the welfare of others
BREIF: Someone who is altruistic always puts others first. An altruistic firefighter risks his life to save another's life, while an altruistic mom gives up the last bite of pie so her kid will be happy.
ADJECTIVE: showing unselfish concern for the welfare of others

MEANING: concerned with practical matters
BREIF: To describe a person or a solution that takes a realistic approach, consider the adjective pragmatic. The four-year-old who wants a unicorn for her birthday isn't being very pragmatic.
NOUN: an imperial decree that becomes part of the fundamental law of the land
ADJECTIVE: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory

MEANING: marked by excessive enthusiasm for a cause or idea
BREIF: If you are excessively enthusiastic about something — a sports team, an actor, your religion, saving the whales, a certain brand of chocolate — then you are fanatical about it.
ADJECTIVE: marked by excessive enthusiasm for and intense devotion to a cause or idea

MEANING: an unchanging intonation
BREIF: Monotone is a droning, unchanging tone. Nothing can put you to sleep quite as effectively as a teacher talking in a monotone.
NOUN: a single tone repeated with different words or different rhythms (especially in rendering liturgical texts)
ADJECTIVE: of a sequence or function; consistently increasing and never decreasing or consistently decreasing and never increasing in value

NOUN: an unchanging intonation
ADJECTIVE: sounded or spoken in a tone unvarying in pitch

MEANING: very hard native crystalline carbon valued as a gem
BREIF: If you stubbornly refuse to change your mind about something, you are adamant about it.
NOUN: very hard native crystalline carbon valued as a gem
ADJECTIVE: impervious to pleas, persuasion, requests, or reason

MEANING: shrewdness shown by keen insight
BREIF: If you have acumen, you are very sharp at what you do. You hope your accountant and your surgeon are both known for their acumen.
NOUN: a tapering point
shrewdness shown by keen insight

MEANING: anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day
BREIF: Something that is fleeting or short-lived is ephemeral, like a fly that lives for one day or text messages flitting from cellphone to cellphone.
NOUN: anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day in its winged form
ADJECTIVE: lasting a very short time

MEANING: embellish; increase the scope, power, or importance of
BREIF: If you are a window washer, but you refer to yourself as a "vista enhancement specialist," then you are aggrandizing your job title — that is, making it sound greater than it is.

MEANING: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
BREIF: If something is boring and unoriginal, it's banal. Banal things are dull as dishwater.
ADJECTIVE: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

MEANING: marked by precise accordance with details
BREIF: Someone who is meticulous pays extreme attention to detail. If that person is, say, your surgeon or your accountant, you'll definitely want them to be meticulous!
ADJECTIVE: marked by extreme care in treatment of details
marked by precise accordance with details

MEANING: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual
BREIF: You're most likely to encounter the adjective eccentric in a description of an unusual or quirky person — like a scatterbrained aunt who leaves her life savings to her cat.
NOUN: a person of a specified kind (usually with many eccentricities)
ADJECTIVE: not having a common center; not concentric

NOUN: a person with an unusual or odd personality
ADJECTIVE: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual

MEANING: troubled persistently, especially with petty annoyances
BREIF: Someone who is harried is feeling the stress of being rushed, overworked, or harassed. A harried parent might be exhausted but still have to make 3 dozen cupcakes for school and help with a science project.
ADJECTIVE: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances

MEANING: similar or equivalent in some respects
BREIF: Use the adjective analogous to describe something that is similar to something else and can be compared to another.
ADJECTIVE: corresponding in function but not in evolutionary origin
similar or equivalent in some respects though otherwise dissimilar

MEANING: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
BREIF: Hackneyed is a word for language that doesn't pack a punch since it's overused and trite. "Roses are red, violets are..." — enough already?! That's hackneyed stuff.
ADJECTIVE: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

MEANING: fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind
BREIF: The trunk of some people's cars may contain items as disparate as old clothes, rotting food, and possibly a missing relative. Disparate things are very different from each other.
ADJECTIVE: including markedly dissimilar elements
fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind

MEANING: of high moral or intellectual value
BREIF: In common use, sublime is an adjective meaning "awe-inspiringly grand, excellent, or impressive," like the best chocolate fudge sundae you've ever had.
VERB: vaporize and then condense right back again
ADJECTIVE: lifted up or set high

VERB: change or cause to change directly from a solid into a vapor without first melting
ADJECTIVE: of high moral or intellectual value; elevated in nature or style

MEANING: not clear to the understanding
BREIF: Something that's enigmatic is tough to figure out. It's puzzling and even mysterious, like those weird secret college societies, Mona Lisa's smile, or the New York Times crossword.
ADJECTIVE: resembling an oracle in obscurity of thought
not clear to the understanding

MEANING: lacking interest or significance or impact
BREIF: Something insipid is lacking in flavor or interest. You'll probably find the generic poems inside of greeting cards insipid.
ADJECTIVE: lacking taste or flavor or tang
lacking interest or significance or impact

MEANING: believe especially on uncertain or tentative grounds
BREIF: Can you guess what conjecture means? It's a word to use when you are not sure of something and have to "guess or surmise."
VERB: believe especially on uncertain or tentative grounds
NOUN: a message expressing an opinion based on incomplete evidence

VERB: believe especially on uncertain or tentative grounds
NOUN: reasoning that involves the formation of conclusions from incomplete evidence

VERB: believe especially on uncertain or tentative grounds
NOUN: a hypothesis that has been formed by speculating or conjecturing (usually with little hard evidence)

MEANING: brief and to the point
BREIF: Laconic is an adjective that describes a style of speaking or writing that uses only a few words, often to express complex thoughts and ideas.  A more laconic way to write that last sentence might be this: laconic means brief.
ADJECTIVE: brief and to the point; effectively cut short

MEANING: demanding immediate attention
BREIF: When you describe something as exigent, you are saying it requires attention: it can't be ignored.
ADJECTIVE: requiring precise accuracy
demanding attention

MEANING: express a negative opinion of
BREIF: If you haven't got anything nice to say, then it's time to disparage someone. It means to belittle or degrade a person or idea.

MEANING: of or involving dispute or controversy
BREIF: The adjective polemical describes something related to an argument or controversy. To keep the peace, avoid discussing politics at Thanksgiving, which usually deteriorates into a polemical argument with Uncle Bob. Better stick to football or apple versus pumpkin pie.
ADJECTIVE: of or involving dispute or controversy

MEANING: harshness of manner
BREIF: Asperity is the harsh tone or behavior people exhibit when they’re angry, impatient, or just miserable. Did your supervisor snap “Late again!” when you showed up 20 minutes after your shift was supposed to start? She's speaking with asperity.
NOUN: something hard to endure
harshness of manner

MEANING: an insufficient quantity or number
BREIF: If there is a dearth of something, there is not enough of it. A dearth of cupcakes is unfortunate, but a dearth of nutritious food is a serious problem.
NOUN: an acute insufficiency
an insufficient quantity or number

MEANING: the state of being disregarded or forgotten
BREIF: Oblivion is the state of being forgotten. Your uncle dreamed of being a rock star, but after recording one hit song, he faded into oblivion.
NOUN: total forgetfulness
the state of being disregarded or forgotten

MEANING: a person who is older than 12 but younger than 20
BREIF: Adolescent is just a fancy word for teenager — someone who is no longer a child but is not yet an adult. The word can also be used as an adjective. For example, a particular clothing line might be geared toward adolescent girls.
NOUN: a juvenile between the onset of puberty and maturity
ADJECTIVE: relating to or peculiar to or suggestive of an adolescent

NOUN: a juvenile between the onset of puberty and maturity
ADJECTIVE: in the state of development between puberty and maturity

NOUN: a juvenile between the onset of puberty and maturity
ADJECTIVE: being of the age 13 through 19

NOUN: a juvenile between the onset of puberty and maturity
ADJECTIVE: displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity

MEANING: an act of shocking cruelty
BREIF: Atrocities, acts of outrageous cruelty, are often committed during wars and armed conflicts.
NOUN: the quality of being shockingly cruel and inhumane
an act of atrocious cruelty

MEANING: lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike
BREIF: If you feel that something isn't worthy of your consideration, you may disdain it (or treat it with disdain).
NOUN: a communication that indicates lack of respect by patronizing the recipient
lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike

MEANING: not straightforward or candid
BREIF: Use the adjective disingenuous to describe behavior that's not totally honest or sincere. It's disingenuous when people pretend to know less about something than they really do.
ADJECTIVE: not straightforward or candid; giving a false appearance of frankness

MEANING: defiantly aggressive
BREIF: If you are quick to argue, always looking for a fight, and hard to please, you are truculent. You can also write a truculent essay, and fans upset by a loss can become truculent.
ADJECTIVE: defiantly aggressive

MEANING: being present everywhere at once
BREIF: It's everywhere! It's everywhere! When something seems like it's present in all places at the same time, reach for the adjective ubiquitous.
ADJECTIVE: being present everywhere at once

MEANING: more than is needed, desired, or required
BREIF: When something is so unnecessary that it could easily be done away with, like a fifth wheel on a car or a fifth person on a double date, call it superfluous.
ADJECTIVE: serving no useful purpose; having no excuse for being
more than is needed, desired, or required

MEANING: give evidence for
BREIF: To corroborate is to back someone else’s story. If you swear to your teacher that you didn't throw the spitball, and your friends corroborate your story by promising that you were concentrating on math homework, she might actually believe you.
VERB: establish or strengthen as with new evidence or facts
support with evidence or authority or make more certain or confirm

MEANING: found in the ordinary course of events
BREIF: An ordinary, unexciting thing can be called mundane: "Superman hid his heroic feats by posing as his mundane alter ego, Clark Kent."
ADJECTIVE: belonging to this earth or world; not ideal or heavenly
found in the ordinary course of events
concerned with the world or worldly matters

MEANING: concurrence of opinion
BREIF: An accord is an agreement between groups or even nations, like a formal peace accord that prevents war or the accord between you and your sister specifying who gets to use the car on which days.
NOUN: a written agreement between two states or sovereigns
concurrence of opinion

MEANING: actions that cause great irritation
BREIF: If you've ever become so frustrated with someone or something that you feel like you're at the end of your rope, you have experienced exasperation. You are fed up!
NOUN: an exasperated feeling of annoyance
actions that cause great irritation (or even anger)

MEANING: standing above others in quality or position
BREIF: Anyone highly regarded or prominent is eminent. Eminent people are very successful at their jobs. If you’ve heard of Neil deGrasse Tyson, it’s probably because he’s an eminent astrophysicist.
ADJECTIVE: of imposing height; especially standing out above others
standing above others in quality or position
(used of persons) standing above others in character or attainment or reputation
having an illustrious reputation; respected

MEANING: unclearness by virtue of having more than one meaning
BREIF: Something with ambiguity is unclear. Think about the sentence, "Jill saw the man with binoculars." If you are wondering whether Jill or the man had the binoculars, you are noticing the ambiguity, or the double meaning, of this sentence.
NOUN: an expression whose meaning cannot be determined from its context
unclearness by virtue of having more than one meaning

MEANING: a state or condition markedly different from the norm
BREIF: An aberration is something strange that rarely occurs. An example of an aberration is when the temperature in Minnesota hits 90 degrees in January — it's nice and warm, but it's really strange.
NOUN: an optical phenomenon resulting from the failure of a lens or mirror to produce a good image
a state or condition markedly different from the norm
a disorder in one's mental state

MEANING: a tendency to try to please or yield to the will of others
BREIF: Complaisance is a quality of being eager to please or happy to follow instructions. Your new puppy's complaisance is going to make her easy to train.
NOUN: a disposition or tendency to yield to the will of others

MEANING: marked by tenacious unwillingness to yield
BREIF: When someone is beyond stubborn, use the word obstinate instead: "You obstinate old mule! Get out of my way!"
ADJECTIVE: resistant to guidance or discipline

MEANING: intelligence manifested by being astute
NOUN: intelligence manifested by being astute (as in business dealings)

MEANING: having or showing profound knowledge
BREIF: If you call someone erudite, that means they show great learning. After you've earned your second Ph.D., you will be truly erudite.
ADJECTIVE: having or showing profound knowledge

MEANING: end, especially to reach a final or climactic stage
BREIF: The verb culminate is used to describe a high point or a climactic stage in a process. For example, the goal of a Major League baseball team is to have their season culminate in a World Series victory.
VERB: rise to, or form, a summit
end, especially to reach a final or climactic stage
bring to a head or to the highest point
reach the highest or most decisive point

MEANING: agree or express agreement
BREIF: To acquiesce is to agree to something or to give in. If your kid sister is refusing to hand over the television remote, you hope she acquiesces before your favorite show comes on.

MEANING: lack of self-assurance
BREIF: The noun diffidence refers to a lack of self-confidence. Your diffidence might be the reason why you never say "hi" to the cute guy or gal in the elevator or why you never ask for a raise.
NOUN: lack of self-confidence

MEANING: free somebody from an erroneous belief
BREIF: Disabuse means to free someone of a belief that is not true. Many teachers of health find that when they teach, they spend as much energy disabusing kids of false beliefs as they do giving them the facts.

MEANING: not serious in content, attitude, or behavior
BREIF: Frivolous things are silly or unnecessary. If something is frivolous, then you don't need it.
ADJECTIVE: not serious in content or attitude or behavior

MEANING: be undecided about something
BREIF: Vacillate means to waver back and forth, unable to decide. You might vacillate between ordering waffles and pancakes at your favorite diner — it’s hard to pick just one when both are so tasty!
VERB: move or sway in a rising and falling or wavelike pattern
be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action

MEANING: correct behavior
BREIF: Propriety is following what is socially acceptable in speech and behavior. Your little brother might offend your sense of propriety by burping loudly at the dinner table.
NOUN: correct or appropriate behavior

MEANING: excessively mournful
BREIF: Funerals are lugubrious. So are rainy days and Mondays. Anything that makes you sad, gloomy, or mournful can be called lugubrious.
ADJECTIVE: excessively mournful

MEANING: stubbornly unyielding
BREIF: If something is persistent, it just won't stop. If you're persistent in your suggestions for a trip to Mexico, maybe your parents will eventually give in and take you there.
ADJECTIVE: retained; not shed
stubbornly unyielding
never-ceasing
continually recurring to the mind

MEANING: incapable of being appeased or pacified
BREIF: An implacable person just can’t be appeased. If you really offended your best friend and tried every kind of apology but she refused to speak to you again, you could describe her as implacable.
ADJECTIVE: incapable of being placated

MEANING: stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing
BREIF: Obdurate is a formal word meaning stubborn. If you want to major in English, but your parents are obdurate that you should go premed, they might go so far as to threaten not to pay your tuition.
ADJECTIVE: showing unfeeling resistance to tender feelings
stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing

MEANING: refrain from doing, consuming, or partaking in something
BREIF: If you abstain from something, you restrain yourself from consuming it. People usually abstain from things that are considered vices — like eating French fries every day for lunch.

VERB: choose not to partake in or consume

MEANING: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought
BREIF: Someone impetuous acts too hastily or carelessly. Hotheaded, impulsive folks are impetuous.
ADJECTIVE: marked by violent force
characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation

MEANING: propriety in manners and conduct
BREIF: Decorum is proper and polite behavior. If you let out a big belch at a fancy dinner party, you're not showing much decorum.
NOUN: the fitness of a composition’s style to its subject
propriety in manners and conduct

MEANING: expressing yourself readily, clearly, effectively
BREIF: When you're eloquent, you have a way with words. An eloquent speaker expresses herself clearly and powerfully. Even though eloquent usually describes oral speech, it can also be used to describe powerful writing.
ADJECTIVE: expressing yourself readily, clearly, effectively

MEANING: peculiarly fortunate or appropriate
BREIF: If your best friend pulls up beside you in her convertible just as your bike gets a flat tire, you could call it providential, or magically lucky.
ADJECTIVE: resulting from divine providence
peculiarly fortunate or appropriate; as if by divine intervention
relating to or characteristic of providence

MEANING: great in size, force, extent, or degree
BREIF: Something exceptional, substantial, or great is prodigious. A blizzard includes prodigious wind and snow. A prodigious writer is one who can write a lot and do it well.
ADJECTIVE: of momentous or ominous significance
so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
far beyond what is usual in magnitude or degree

MEANING: a feeling of strong eagerness
BREIF: Zeal is dedication or enthusiasm for something. If you have zeal, you're willing, energized, and motivated.
NOUN: excessive fervor to do something or accomplish some end
a feeling of strong eagerness (usually in favor of a person or cause)
prompt willingness

MEANING: displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity
BREIF: Some people like their movies to have sophisticated humor and others prefer the more puerile humor of pratfalls or jokes about smelly underwear, inappropriate belching, and passing gas.
ADJECTIVE: of or characteristic of a child
displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity

MEANING: make obscure or unclear
BREIF: Some people are experts at obfuscating the truth by being evasive, unclear, or obscure in the telling of the facts. The people who are good at obfuscating would include defense lawyers and teenagers asked about their plans for Saturday night.

MEANING: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
BREIF: Use the noun apathy when someone isn't interested in the important things that are happening. You might feel apathy for the political process after watching candidates bicker tediously with one another.
NOUN: the trait of lacking enthusiasm for or interest in things generally
an absence of emotion or enthusiasm

MEANING: showing or motivated by sympathy and understanding
BREIF: Choose the adjective benevolent for someone who does good deeds or shows goodwill. If your teacher collects homework with a benevolent smile, she's hoping that you've done a good job.
ADJECTIVE: generous in assistance to the poor
showing or motivated by sympathy and understanding and generosity
intending or showing kindness
generous in providing aid to others

MEANING: an unpleasant or difficult situation
BREIF: If you're engaged to get married but suddenly fall in love with someone else, you have gotten yourself into quite a predicament. A predicament is a difficult, confusing, and unpleasant situation.
NOUN: a situation from which extrication is difficult especially an unpleasant or trying one

MEANING: place limits on
BREIF: Confine is all about setting limits. If you are confined to the house, it means you can't leave it. If you're really sick, you might be confined to your bed.

VERB: restrict or confine, "I limit you to two visits to the pub a day"
deprive of freedom; take into confinement

MEANING: the immediate descendants of a person
BREIF: Progeny means "offspring" or "children." You and your brothers are the progeny of your parents, and your cat's new litter of kittens is her progeny.
NOUN: the immediate descendants of a person

MEANING: the range of skills in a particular field or occupation
BREIF: Repertoire refers to the full supply of what you can do. A singer's repertoire is all the songs he can sing. A chef's repertoire is what she knows how to cook.
NOUN: a collection of works (plays, songs, operas, ballets) that an artist or company can perform and do perform for short intervals on a regular schedule
the entire range of skills or aptitudes or devices used in a particular field or occupation

MEANING: urged or forced to action through moral pressure
ADJECTIVE: urged or forced to action through moral pressure

MEANING: cut or impressed into a surface
ADJECTIVE: cut or impressed into a surface

MEANING: move about in or as if in a predatory manner
BREIF: If you move stealthily — like you're looking for something to prey on — then you prowl. Your cat might prowl around the room and pounce on your feet, which is cute if you're awake, but annoying when you're asleep.
VERB: loiter about, with no apparent aim
NOUN: the act of prowling (walking about in a stealthy manner)

MEANING: a natural inclination
BREIF: A propensity is a natural tendency to behave in a certain way. We all have propensities — things we tend to do. Dogs have a propensity to bark, and many people have a propensity for getting annoyed by it.
NOUN: a disposition to behave in a certain way
a natural inclination
an inclination to do something

MEANING: get the meaning of something
BREIF: To comprehend something is to understand it, like when you have to read a difficult passage more than once in order to comprehend it.
VERB: include in scope; include as part of something broader; have as one's sphere or territory
become aware of through the senses

MEANING: in an exhaustive manner
BREIF: Thoroughly means exhaustively and completely. No matter how thoroughly you clean every carpet, shelf, and windowpane in a house, there is always more dust to be found.
ADVERB: completely and absolutely (`good' is sometimes used informally for `thoroughly')

MEANING: containing or characterized by mistakes
BREIF: The adjective erroneous describes something or someone as mistaken and incorrect. Early explorers had the erroneous notion that the oceans were full of dragons.
ADJECTIVE: containing or characterized by error

MEANING: choose and follow a theory, idea, policy, etc.
BREIF: Use the verb espouse to describe the actions of someone who lives according to specific beliefs, such as your friends who espouse environmentalism and as a result walk whenever possible instead of taking the car.

VERB: choose and follow; as of theories, ideas, policies, strategies or plans
take up the cause, ideology, practice, method, of someone and use it as one's own

MEANING: containing or based on incorrect reasoning
BREIF: Something fallacious is a mistake that comes from too little information or unsound sources. Predictions that the whole state of California will snap off from the rest of North America and float away have proven to be fallacious — for now, anyway.
ADJECTIVE: intended to deceive
containing or based on a fallacy
based on an incorrect or misleading notion or information

MEANING: characterized by resoluteness and firmness
BREIF: If you make decisions quickly, you are someone who is decisive. A decisive event can settle something, like a war.
ADJECTIVE: unmistakable
characterized by decision and firmness
determining or having the power to determine an outcome
forming or having the nature of a turning point or crisis

MEANING: the act of creating written works
NOUN: the act of creating written works

MEANING: the act of implementing the control of equipment
BREIF: Automation means making something automatic, or mechanized. If there's smoke in your house and your smoke detector is set up to "call" the fire department, that's an example of automation.
NOUN: the condition of being automatically operated or controlled
the act of implementing the control of equipment with advanced technology; usually involving electronic hardware
equipment used to achieve automatic control or operation

MEANING: fully understood or grasped
ADJECTIVE: fully understood or grasped

MEANING: a military training exercise
VERB: direct the course; determine the direction of travelling
NOUN: an action aimed at evading an opponent

VERB: act in order to achieve a certain goal
NOUN: a military training exercise

VERB: perform a movement in military or naval tactics in order to secure an advantage in attack or defense
NOUN: a plan for attaining a particular goal

MEANING: sufficiently valuable to justify the investment of time
BREIF: Things that are worthwhile are good — they're worth the time or money you spend on them.
ADJECTIVE: sufficiently valuable to justify the investment of time or interest

MEANING: with full knowledge and deliberation
conspicuous in position or importance
BREIF: If you're looking for an adjective that means "sticking out above the rest; famous," consider prominent. A prominent person might be the big star, the head honcho, the top dog — not just any ordinary person.
ADJECTIVE: having a quality that thrusts itself into attention
conspicuous in position or importance

MEANING: an engine providing medieval artillery used during sieges
BREIF: A catapult is something that hurls things through the air, like a catapult that sends pumpkins flying in an annual Halloween competition.
VERB: hurl as if with a sling
NOUN: a plaything consisting of a Y-shaped stick with elastic between the arms; used to propel small stones

VERB: shoot forth or launch, as if from a catapult
NOUN: an engine that provided medieval artillery used during sieges; a heavy war engine for hurling large stones and other missiles

MEANING: surrounded by hostile forces
ADJECTIVE: surrounded by hostile forces

MEANING: an unshakable belief in something without need for proof
BREIF: A conviction is something certain: a judgment of guilty in court and a strong belief are both convictions.
NOUN: (criminal law) a final judgment of guilty in a criminal case and the punishment that is imposed
an unshakable belief in something without need for proof or evidence

MEANING: capable of arousing and holding the attention
BREIF: Compelling means attractive, or irresistible, or really, really convincing. You know your argument for backpacking across Europe is compelling when your parents not only let you go but also pay for all your expenses.
ADJECTIVE: driving or forcing
capable of arousing and holding the attention
tending to persuade by forcefulness of argument

MEANING: make clear and comprehensible
BREIF: If you elucidate something, you explain it very clearly. If you don't understand fractions, a visit to the pie shop may elucidate the subject for you.
VERB: make free from confusion or ambiguity; make clear

MEANING: one of a pair of long straps used to control a horse
BREIF: Rein is both a noun and a verb for guiding and restraining. You can use the long strap, or rein, on a horse to control its speed and direction, and you can rein in your own tongue by closing your mouth.
VERB: stop or slow up one's horse or oneself by or as if by pulling the reins
NOUN: any means of control

VERB: control and direct with or as if by reins
NOUN: one of a pair of long straps (usually connected to the bit or the headpiece) used to control a horse

VERB: stop or check by or as if by a pull at the reins
NOUN: one of a pair of long straps (usually connected to the bit or the headpiece) used to control a horse
one of a pair of long straps (usually connected to the bit or the headpiece) used to control a horse

MEANING: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing
BREIF: Something incessant continues without interruption. When you're on a cross-country flight, it's tough to tolerate the incessant crying of a baby.
ADJECTIVE: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing

MEANING: move hesitatingly, as if about to give way
BREIF: Falter means to hesitate, stumble, or waver, and everything from faith to voices can do it. So if you want to keep your bride or groom happy, it's best not to falter when it's your turn to say "I do."
NOUN: the act of pausing uncertainly

MEANING: carve or cut a design or letters into
BREIF: If you etch something you are cutting into it. You can etch "I ♥ U" into a tree trunk with a pocket knife or etch your initials in your desk with a key (if the teacher's not looking).
VERB: cause to stand out or be clearly defined or visible
carve or cut a design or letters into
carve or cut into a block used for printing or print from such a block
selectively dissolve the surface of (a semiconductor or printed circuit) with a solvent, laser, or stream of electrons

MEANING: long past
BREIF: Anything immemorial is very, very old. You're most likely to hear this word in the phrase "time immemorial," a common way to say "so long ago that no one remembers it."
ADJECTIVE: long past; beyond the limits of memory or tradition or recorded history

MEANING: turn up, loosen, or remove earth
BREIF: The verb delve means to dig into, loosen, or investigate. She delved into her family's history and discovered an inventor, a checkers champion, and a circus equestrian in her ancestry.
VERB: consider in detail and subject to an analysis in order to discover essential features or meaning
turn up, loosen, or remove earth
search for something in a receptacle or container

MEANING: indicate by signs
BREIF: The verb bode suggests forecasting. Something bodes well when the clues or signs imply a favorable outcome. But if something bodes ill, you’d better watch out!

MEANING: freedom from activity
BREIF: Repose is a formal or literary term used to mean the act of resting, or the state of being at rest. Repose is also a state of mind: freedom from worry.
NOUN: a disposition free from stress or emotion

VERB: lean in a comfortable resting position
NOUN: freedom from activity (work or strain or responsibility)
the absence of mental stress or anxiety
the absence of mental stress or anxiety

MEANING: without principles
BREIF: Use the adjective unscrupulous to describe someone who behaves in a dishonest or unethical way.
ADJECTIVE: without scruples or principles

MEANING: the shape or manner in which things come together
BREIF: A juncture is a crucial point in time when a decision must be made. At this juncture, a president might say, the government must decide whether to go ahead with war or to try to solve things diplomatically.
NOUN: a crisis situation or point in time when a critical decision must be made
the shape or manner in which things come together and a connection is made
an event that occurs at a critical time

MEANING: a linear unit of measurement for water depth
BREIF: To fathom something is to understand it thoroughly. It's usually used in the negative, as in "I can't fathom why he doesn't want to go along with us."
NOUN: (mining) a unit of volume (equal to 6 cubic feet) used in measuring bodies of ore

VERB: measure the depth of (a body of water) with a sounding line
NOUN: a linear unit of measurement (equal to 6 feet) for water depth

MEANING: quietly and steadily persevering in detail or exactness
BREIF: Someone who is diligent works hard and carefully. If you want to write the epic history of your family, you'll have to be very diligent in tracking down and interviewing all of your relatives.
ADJECTIVE: characterized by care and perseverance in carrying out tasks
quietly and steadily persevering especially in detail or exactness

MEANING: deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
BREIF: Losing a football game stinks, but losing a game where, at the end, you are lying face down in a puddle of mud and the fans are burning effigies of you in the streets? That is an ignominious defeat.
ADJECTIVE: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame

MEANING: existing in abundance
BREIF: At a party with more cupcakes than anyone could imagine, you’ll hear guests say, “There are cupcakes galore!”  Galore means there’s so much that it’s unbelievable.
ADJECTIVE: in great numbers
existing in abundance

MEANING: take in liquids
BREIF: Imbibe is a fancy word for "drink."  If you need to imbibe ten cups of coffee just to get out of the house, you might have a caffeine problem.
VERB: receive into the mind and retain
take (gas, light or heat) into a solution

MEANING: with concise and precise brevity; to the point
BREIF: To say something succinctly is to say it briefly, fitting your points into one concise statement. It's a talent rarely enjoyed and much appreciated.  You succinctly stated your case and sat down to great applause, not to mention great relief.
ADVERB: with concise and precise brevity; to the point

MEANING: an arrangement of objects or persons one behind another
BREIF: Tandem describes an arrangement where people or animals are in formation, one behind the other. Couples attached at the hip sometimes like to ride tandem bicycles, which allow two people to pedal the same bike. How cute.
NOUN: a bicycle with two sets of pedals and two seats

MEANING: not restrained or controlled
BREIF: Unbridled means unrestrained. When you find out that you just won the lottery, feel free to jump up and down with unbridled joy. Go ahead, most people would probably let loose in the same way.
ADJECTIVE: not restrained or controlled

MEANING: very sentimental or emotional
BREIF: You can use maudlin to describe something that brings tears to your eyes, or makes you feel very emotional. Tearjerkers like "Forrest Gump" and "Titanic" can be described as maudlin.
ADJECTIVE: effusively or insincerely emotional

MEANING: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering
BREIF: To wheedle is to sweet talk, or flatter someone in the hopes of getting something in return. You might try to wheedle a meter maid into not giving you a parking ticket. Good luck with that.
VERB: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering

MEANING: the act of relieving ills and changing for the better
BREIF: Amelioration is a process that makes something better. A philanthropist might devote her life to the amelioration of poverty and hunger.
NOUN: the act of relieving ills and changing for the better

MEANING: hang over, as of something threatening, dark, or menacing
BREIF: A brood is a group of young born at the same time — like a brood of chicks — but your parents might use the word for you and your siblings: "We're taking the whole brood to the movies tonight."
NOUN: the young of an animal cared for at one time

MEANING: an odd or fanciful or capricious idea
BREIF: Whimsy is what a person who's a dreamer and out of step with the real world might have lots of. People who are full of whimsy are odd, but often fanciful and lovely, like Harry Potter's friend Luna Lovegood.
NOUN: the trait of acting unpredictably and more from whim or caprice than from reason or judgment
an odd or fanciful or capricious idea

MEANING: varying in color when seen in different lights or from different angles
ADJECTIVE: varying in color when seen in different lights or from different angles

MEANING: mix together different elements
BREIF: Conflate is a more formal way to say "mix together," and it's typically used for texts or ideas. You probably wouldn't say you conflated the ingredients for a cake, but if you blended two different stories together to make a new one, conflate would work.

MEANING: go back to something earlier
surround so as to force to give up
BREIF: To besiege means to attack with an army, or to pester with many requests. When all your teachers ask you to hand in assignments on the same day, you can end up feeling besieged.
VERB: cause to feel distressed or worried
surround so as to force to give up
harass, as with questions or requests

MEANING: anticipate with dread or anxiety
BREIF: To apprehend is to capture or arrest, as when the police try to apprehend criminals and bring them to justice. You also apprehend a concept when you understand it, grasping or capturing its meaning.

VERB: understand or perceive the meaning of something

MEANING: requiring attention or action
BREIF: When something absolutely has to be done and cannot be put off, use the adjective imperative.
NOUN: a mood that expresses an intention to influence the listener's behavior
ADJECTIVE: relating to verbs in the imperative mood

NOUN: some duty that is essential and urgent
ADJECTIVE: requiring attention or action

MEANING: force somebody to do something
BREIF: Compel means to force or drive someone to do something. Even if you don't like toast, when you visit the toast-eating natives of Shrintakook Island, you'll be compelled to eat it, or they will not trust you.

MEANING: make strong or stronger
BREIF: If you add nutrients to something you fortify it. Food scientists have found ways to fortify cereal, but in addition to vitamins C and D, they usually add a lot of sugar.
VERB: prepare oneself for a military confrontation

MEANING: have as a logical consequence
BREIF: To entail is to involve. A job at a movie theater might entail sweeping popcorn off the floor, probably because watching a movie entails eating popcorn in the dark. It’s a small price to pay!
VERB: limit the inheritance of property to a specific class of heirs
NOUN: the act of entailing property; the creation of a fee tail from a fee simple
land received by fee tail

MEANING: marked by sound judgment
BREIF: Describe an action as prudent if it is the wise thing to do under the existing circumstances. If you're getting in trouble, it is probably prudent to keep your mouth closed and just listen.
ADJECTIVE: careful and sensible; marked by sound judgment

MEANING: be relevant to
BREIF: To pertain is to be relevant or somehow associated with something.  If you're a lawyer, you try to find evidence that will pertain to the case and eliminate anything that is not connected.
VERB: be a part or attribute of

MEANING: filled with or attended with
BREIF: Fraught means filled with something — often something bad. Your Thanksgiving was fraught with awkward moments when your family saw your blue hair, and it only got worse when you told them you'd quit law school to join the circus.
ADJECTIVE: marked by distress
filled with or attended with

MEANING: give as a gift
BREIF: When you present an honor or a gift to someone, you bestow it, which is the same as giving it, but often classier and more respectful.

MEANING: spoken with particular stress
BREIF: Emphatic means forceful and clear. Nicole's mother was emphatic when she told her not to come home late again.
ADJECTIVE: forceful and definite in expression or action
spoken with emphasis
sudden and strong

MEANING: deliver a sermon
BREIF: To preach is to deliver a sermon or an otherwise powerful message. You may go to church to hear the minister preach, and you may preach tolerance to your friends.
VERB: speak, plead, or argue in favor of

MEANING: attempt by employing effort
BREIF: When you endeavor to do something, you try hard to make it happen. A determined student might endeavor to get straight As on her report card.
NOUN: a purposeful or industrious undertaking (especially one that requires effort or boldness)
earnest and conscientious activity intended to do or accomplish something

MEANING: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences
BREIF: A precedent is something that sets a standard for future events. It's hard to say what the legal community would do without the word precedent, since so many legal judgments and decisions are based on what came before.
NOUN: a subject mentioned earlier (preceding in time)
ADJECTIVE: preceding in time, order, or significance

MEANING: make happy or satisfied
BREIF:
To gratify is to satisfy. Bringing home an A in math would gratify your math tutor. 
Gratify can also mean to give in. You probably shouldn't gratify your urge to scream in class.

MEANING: hard, monotonous, routine work
BREIF: If you’ve ever had to do the laundry, wash the dishes, make the meals, change the bedding, vacuum the house, and clean the bathrooms day after day, you’ve experienced drudgery. Drudgery is hard, mindless, backbreaking work.
NOUN: hard monotonous routine work

MEANING: originating where it is found
BREIF: Use the adjective autochthonous to say that something is native to an area. If kane toads originated in your area, then they’re an autochthonous species.
ADJECTIVE: of rocks, deposits, etc.; found where they and their constituents were formed
originating where it is found

MEANING: fill to satisfaction
BREIF: If you just can't get enough popcorn, even the jumbo tub at the movie theater may not be enough to satiate, or satisfy, your desire.
VERB: overeat or eat immodestly; make a pig of oneself
ADJECTIVE: supplied (especially fed) to satisfaction

MEANING: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose
BREIF: A clique is an exclusive group of people or friends. Before Rudolph pulled Santa's sled through the fog, the clique of flying reindeer never let him play their reindeer games.
NOUN: an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose

MEANING: be confusing or perplexing to
BREIF: To befuddle is to confuse. A sticky exam question can befuddle you, or an awkward question about your whereabouts the night before (how can you remember? You were befuddled, after all.)

VERB: be confusing or perplexing to; cause to be unable to think clearly

MEANING: an assistant to a bishop
NOUN: an assistant to a bishop

MEANING: an offensive against an enemy
BREIF: Onslaught is a military term that refers to an attack against an enemy. It's safe to say that no one wants to be caught on the receiving end of an onslaught, because there will be lots of danger, destruction and probably death.
NOUN: the rapid and continuous delivery of linguistic communication (spoken or written)
(military) an offensive against an enemy (using weapons)
a sudden and severe onset of trouble

MEANING: a crime that undermines the offender's government
BREIF: Hacking your brother’s email account and sharing all his secrets with your mom could be considered an act of personal treason, meaning you have betrayed your brother.
NOUN: an act of deliberate betrayal
a crime that undermines the offender's government
disloyalty by virtue of subversive behavior

MEANING: the psychological result of perception and reasoning
BREIF: Cognition is the act of thinking, perceiving, and understanding. It's cognition that makes it possible for you to learn a foreign language.
NOUN: the psychological result of perception and learning and reasoning

MEANING: a series of sentinels or posts enclosing some place or thing
BREIF: That yellow police tape and group of officers encircling the crime scene? That's a kind of cordon — something set up to guard something.
NOUN: adornment consisting of an ornamental ribbon or cord
a series of sentinels or of military posts enclosing or guarding some place or thing
cord or ribbon worn as an insignia of honor or rank

MEANING: get by special effort
BREIF: In prison movies, there's always a character who is able to procure all sorts of contraband from the inside — magazines, playing cards, special soap. If you procure something, you get it or bring it about by special effort.
VERB: arrange for sexual partners for others

MEANING: no longer in use
BREIF: Use the adjective obsolete for something that is out of date. As the Rolling Stones song "Out of Time" goes, "You're obsolete, my baby, my poor old-fashioned baby."
ADJECTIVE: no longer in use
